content.text: State two SI base units other than the kilogram, metre and second
Show that the SI base units of \(E\) are \(\mathrm{kgm}^2 \mathrm{s}^{-2}\)
The elastic potential energy \(E\) is given by
where \(\rho\) is the density of the metal,
\(g\) is the acceleration of free fall,
\(A\) is the cross-sectional area of the wire
and \(C\) is a constant
Determine the SI base units of \(C\)
SI base units of \(C\)    .........
A metal wire has original length \(l_0\). It is then suspended and hangs vertically as shown in Fig. 1.1
The weight of the wire causes it to stretch. The elastic potential energy stored in the wire is \(E\)
Using Fig. 2.1, determine the distance between the source and the reflector
distance =   .........  m
Determine the time-base setting required to produce the same separation of pulses on the c.r.o. when sound waves are used instead of radio waves
The speed of sound is \(300 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)

A source of radio waves sends a pulse towards a reflector. The pulse returns from the reflector and is detected at the same point as the source. The emitted and reflected pulses are recorded on a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) as shown in Fig. 2.1
The time-base setting is \(0.20 \mu \text{s} \text{cm}^{-1}\)
State what is meant by work done
A trolley of mass \(400\mathrm{g}\) is moving at a constant velocity of \(2.5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the right as shown in Fig. 3.1
Show that the kinetic energy of the trolley is 1.3J
The trolley comes to rest at point Q
Calculate the distance PQ
distance PQ =   .........  m
On Fig. 3.4, sketch the variation with \(x\) of velocity \(v\) for the trolley moving between P and Q
The trolley in **(b)** moves to point P as shown in Fig. 3.2
At point P the speed of the trolley is \(2.5 \text{m s}^{- 1}\)
A variable force \(F\) acts to the left on the trolley as it moves between points P and Q
The variation of \(F\) with displacement \(x\) from P is shown in Fig. 3.3
Define the torque of a couple
List two other forces that act on the wheel. State the direction of these forces and where they act
Calculate the torque of the couple acting on the wheel
torque =   .........  Nm
The resultant force on the wheel is zero. Explain, by reference to the four forces acting on the wheel, how it is possible that the resultant force is zero
State and explain whether the wheel is in equilibrium
A wheel is supported by a pin P at its centre of gravity, as shown in Fig. 4.1
The plane of the wheel is vertical. The wheel has radius \(25\mathrm{cm}\)
Two parallel forces each of \(35\mathrm{N}\) act on the edge of the wheel in the vertical directions shown in Fig. 4.1. Friction between the pin and the wheel is negligible
Explain the term displacement for the wave on the rope
Calculate, for the wave on the rope,
1. the amplitude,
amplitude =   .........  mm
2. the speed
On Fig. 5.1, draw the wave pattern on the rope at a time 0.050s later than that shown
progressive or stationary,
longitudinal or transverse
State and explain whether the waves on the rope are
A long rope is held under tension between two points A and B. Point A is made to vibrate vertically and a wave is sent down the rope towards B as shown in Fig. 5.1

The time for one oscillation of point A on the rope is \(0.20 \text{s}\). The point A moves a distance of \(80 \text{mm}\) during one oscillation. The wave on the rope has a wavelength of \(1.5 \text{m}\)
Define potential difference (p.d.)
Show that the resistance of each wire is \(0.54\Omega\)
Calculate the current in the wires
current =   .........  A
Calculate the power loss in the wires
A power supply of e.m.f. \(240\mathrm{V}\) and zero internal resistance is connected to a heater as shown in Fig. 6.1

The wires used to connect the heater to the power supply each have length \(75\mathrm{m}\). The wires have a cross-sectional area \(2.5\mathrm{mm}^2\) and resistivity \(18\mathrm{n}\Omega \mathrm{m}\). The heater has a constant resistance of \(38\Omega\)

The wires to the heater are replaced by wires of the same length and material but having a cross-sectional area of \(0.50 \text{mm}^2\). Without further calculation, state and explain the effect on the power loss in the wires
State one similarity of the electric fields shown in Fig. 7.1 and Fig. 7.2
The electric field strength in Fig. 7.2 is less than that in Fig. 7.1. State two methods of reducing this electric field strength
By reference to the properties of \(\alpha \text{-particles}\) and \(\beta \text{-particles}\), suggest three reasons for the differences in the deflections shown in Fig. 7.1 and Fig. 7.2
An electric field is set up between two parallel metal plates in a vacuum. The deflection of \(\alpha\) -particles as they pass between the plates is shown in Fig. 7.1
The electric field strength between the plates is reduced. The \(\alpha\) -particles are replaced by \(\beta\) -particles. The deflection of \(\beta\) -particles is shown in Fig. 7.2
A source of \(\alpha \text{-particles}\) is uranium-238. The nuclear reaction for the emission of \(\alpha \text{-particles}\) is represented by
State the values of \(W.\)
X
Y
Z
A source of \(\beta \text{-particles}\) is phosphorus-32. The nuclear reaction for the emission of \(\beta \text{-particles}\) is represented by
State the values of \(A\)
B
C
D
